commit_message:
Send HTTP headers with hyphens to API server

The client currently sends underscores instead of hyphens in the
requests for some HTTP headers. This has been described as a problem
before in the bug that is linked to this commit. And, as the bug
describes, is an issue for server's such as Apache's httpd and nginx.

So in order to address this, the client then will send hyphens in the
headers. This will enable glance to be ran easier over other engines
other than eventlet.

On the other hand, for a while Glance has already supported parsing
headers and replacing hyphens for underscores. So making this change

subject: Dell SC: Disable connectivity failures for new servers
commit_message:
Dell SC: Disable connectivity failures for new servers

The Dell SC driver creates an object on the array called a server
definition for any new hosts it needs to expose a volume to. By default
these server definitions will have an option enabled called
AlertOnConnectivity that will cause alerts to be generated and emails to
be sent if configured.

Since OpenStack controls connecting and disconnecting iSCSI sessions as
needed, this results in false alarms being raised for servers. For
servers used in an OpenStack environment, this flag should be set to
false so alerts on not generated when a server logs out of a target
port.

No unit tests included since I couldn't find a way with existing tests
to not just test that mocking works.

to avoid a KeyError in the subnet_interface_map. However, this led

used and ``location_strategy`` configuration option is set to
``store_type``.

subject: Tag neutron-lib as tc-approved-release
commit_message:
Tag neutron-lib as tc-approved-release

Neutron-lib was created in late 2015 by the Neutron team with the intent
of splitting out stable, reusable library code from the main Neutron
repository. [1]

As such, neutron-lib is an important piece of under-the-hood machinery
for how Neutron functions going forward.  Some or all of it may be a
reasonable candidate for inclusion in future DefCore Interoperability
Guidelines as a Designated Section.  Although as a library project it
does not expose any Capabilities to end users of OpenStack clouds
directly via an API, it does provide code that is or may in the future
be invoked by Capabilities that are required by Interoperability
Guidelines.

At present, the DefCore Committee would be unable to consider adding
part or all of neutron-lib as a Designated Section to future Guidelines
because it isn't designated as part of the TC-approved release. [2]
This means (as an extreme example) that a vendor could entirely replace
neutron-lib with it's own independently created code and still have the
resulting product bear the OpenStack trademark.  By tagging neutron-lib
as tc-approved-release, the DefCore Committee would be allowed to
consider adding Designated Sections to future Guidelines that include
neutron-lib, thereby making the community developed code required.

[1]
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/liberty/neutron-lib.html
[2]
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/defcore/tree/doc/source/process/2016A.rst#n86

Change-Id: I6befe442c31b812f3d3b17b21ac844be96a419b2
